description.en: The descriptive statistics vocabulary provides a controlled set of concepts for describing statistical measures and summary statistics for FAIR data.

definition.en: The sum of all values divided by the number of values.
The nth root of the product of n values.
The reciprocal of the arithmetic mean of reciprocals.
The mean calculated after removing a specified percentage of extreme values from both ends.
The mean calculated after replacing extreme values with less extreme values at specified percentiles.
The most frequently occurring value in a dataset.
The middle value when data are sorted in order.
The smallest value in a dataset.
The largest value in a dataset.
The total obtained by adding all values together.
The 25th percentile, below which 25% of data values fall.
The 50th percentile (median), below which 50% of data values fall.
The 75th percentile, below which 75% of data values fall.
The 20th percentile, below which 20% of data values fall.
The 40th percentile, below which 40% of data values fall.
The 60th percentile, below which 60% of data values fall.
The 80th percentile, below which 80% of data values fall.
The 10th percentile, below which 10% of data values fall.
The 20th percentile, below which 20% of data values fall.
The 30th percentile, below which 30% of data values fall.
The 40th percentile, below which 40% of data values fall.
The 50th percentile (median), below which 50% of data values fall.
The 60th percentile, below which 60% of data values fall.
The 70th percentile, below which 70% of data values fall.
The 80th percentile, below which 80% of data values fall.
The 90th percentile, below which 90% of data values fall.
A percentile value not covered by quartiles, quintiles, or deciles.
The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean.
The difference between the maximum and minimum values.
The average of the squared deviations from the mean.
The square root of the variance, measuring spread around the mean.
The mean of the absolute deviations from a central point (typically the mean).
The median of the absolute deviations from the median, a robust measure of variability.
The difference between the third and first quartiles (Q3 - Q1).
The difference between the fourth and first quintiles.
The difference between the ninth and first deciles (P90 - P10).
A measure of statistical dispersion representing inequality in a distribution.
A robust scale estimator based on the first quartile of pairwise absolute differences.
A robust scale estimator based on median of medians of pairwise absolute differences.
A robust measure of scale based on the biweight (bisquare) function.
The count of observations with valid, non-missing values.
The count of observations with invalid or out-of-range values.
The count of observations with null, missing, or empty values.
The count of distinct values in the dataset.
The proportion of zero or null values in a dataset.
The number of observations with positive values (> 0).
The number of observations with exactly zero value.
The number of observations with negative values (< 0).

prefLabel.en: Number of digits needed to safely store the data

definition.en: The precision or number of significant digits required to represent the values.
The number of times a particular value or category appears.
A count or size measure not otherwise categorized.
The standardized distance of the mode from the mean in standard deviation units.
The ratio of the range to the standard deviation.
The ratio of the standard deviation to the mean, expressing variability relative to the mean.
The proportion of valid observations expressed as a percentage.
The proportion of invalid observations expressed as a percentage.
A relative measure of dispersion based on quartiles: (Q3 - Q1) / (Q3 + Q1).
The fraction of distinct values relative to total observations.
The proportion of observations equal to the mode value.
The proportion of observations with non-zero values.
The proportion of observations with positive values.
The proportion of observations with negative values.
A measure of the asymmetry of the distribution around its mean.
A measure of the tailedness or peakedness of the distribution.
Kurtosis minus 3, measuring deviation from the normal distribution's tailedness.
The standardized third moment about the mean.
A skewness measure based on the third standardized moment.
Skewness calculated with sample-based denominator adjustment.
Skewness calculated assuming the data represents the entire population.
Excess kurtosis calculated with sample-based denominator adjustment.
Excess kurtosis calculated assuming the data represents the entire population.
A quartile-based measure of skewness robust to outliers.
A test statistic for assessing normality of a distribution.
A statistical test for whether a sample comes from a specified distribution.
A nonparametric test for comparing a sample distribution with a reference distribution.
A goodness-of-fit test for normality based on skewness and kurtosis.
The length of the shortest text value in characters.
The length of the longest text value in characters.
The mean length of text values in characters.
The standard deviation of text lengths in characters.
The smallest number of words in any text value.
The largest number of words in any text value.
The mean number of words per text value.
The sum of all words across all text values.
The number of distinct words appearing across all text values.
The ratio of unique words to total words, measuring vocabulary richness.
The set of natural languages detected or present in text values.
Indicates whether values contain only ASCII characters.
The total number of records (rows) in the file.
The total number of variables or columns in the file.
The size of the file measured in bytes.
A hash value used to verify file integrity.
The character encoding used to represent text in the file (e.g., UTF-8).
The compression format or status applied to the file (e.g., gzip).
The schema identifier or version describing the file's structure.
The timestamp when the file was last modified.
The timestamp when the file was originally created.
The media type that describes the file's format (e.g., text/csv).
The ratio of records to variables, indicating dataset shape.
The count of observations with invalid or out-of-range values.
The count of observations with null, missing, or empty values.
The fraction of distinct values relative to total observations.
The proportion of values that are missing or null.
The proportion of values that are present and non-null.
The number of duplicated records based on chosen key(s).
The mean calculated after removing a specified percentage of extreme values from both ends.
The mean calculated after replacing extreme values with less extreme values at specified percentiles.
A robust scale estimator based on the first quartile of pairwise absolute differences.
A robust scale estimator based on median of medians of pairwise absolute differences.
The average of the minimum and maximum values.
A weighted average of the median and two quartiles: (Q1 + 2×Q2 + Q3) / 4.
A robust measure of scale based on the biweight (bisquare) function.
A measure of the joint variability between two variables.
A measure of linear correlation between two variables, ranging from -1 to +1.
A non-parametric measure of rank correlation between two variables.
A measure of ordinal association based on concordant and discordant pairs.
The largest absolute correlation coefficient found in a correlation matrix.
The expected information content per symbol based on its probability distribution.
An exponentiated form of entropy indicating average branching or uncertainty.
The number of observations beyond k×IQR fences from the quartiles.
The number of observations with standardized values exceeding a threshold (e.g., |z|>3).
The most frequent k categories ranked by count.
The cumulative proportion contributed by the top k categories.
A categorization of the number of distinct values into predefined buckets.
The ratio between majority and minority class frequencies.
